body:
DEAR DIARY:
 
I had an unusual experience recently. The morning seemed like a run-of-the-mill weekday. I had just dropped off my daughter for school on Flatbush Avenue in Park Slope and was waiting for a friend and fellow mom to emerge from her car to chat when a man came out of DNY Natural Land. He was carrying a bouquet of roses. Feeling
title: METROPOLITAN DIARY

The search for a suspect in the recent deaths of three Brooklyn shopkeepers ended on Wednesday with the arrest of a clothing dealer whom Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly described as a “serial killer” intent on finding more victims. 
 
The arrest of the clothing dealer, Salvatore Perrone, 64, of Staten Island — who
title: Man Arrested in Deaths of 3 Brooklyn Merchants Is Called ‘Serial Killer’

body:
Detectives searching for a gunman believed to have killed three Brooklyn shopkeepers were interviewing a man on Tuesday evening who resembled a person caught on surveillance footage near the scene of the last murder, a police spokesman said.
 
Asked whether he was a suspect, the spokesman said, “We’re not labeling him
title: Police Interview Man in Connection With Brooklyn Merchant Killings

body:
Police detectives were looking at the possibility of bias as a motive in the recent killings of three Brooklyn shopkeepers of Middle Eastern origin, and were working with federal agents to create a profile of a suspect, the police commissioner, Raymond W. Kelly, said Monday. 
 
Detectives were working under the premise that a single gunman
title: Bias Weighed as Motive in Killings of Brooklyn Shopkeepers

body: OXENHORN--Harry, passed away peacefully on Sunday, November 18th after a brief illness. He was 94 years old. Mr. Oxenhorn served in the US Army, and attained the rank of Captain before his honorable discharge. He was a furrier for over 50 years, where he worked first at the family business of Oxenhom & Sons, and later at Bergdorf Goodman and HBA.
title: Paid Notice: Deaths OXENHORN, HARRY

body: Earlier this month, I visited the large, globular structure of glass and pre-rusted steel that has risen at the intersection of Atlantic and Flatbush Avenues. title: RIFF; ‘The Perfect Team for Brooklynland’

body:
For their most zealous fans, evenings with the New York Islanders have been as unchanging as the seat number on a season ticket: Hop in the car. Enter a fading arena. And in recent years, watch a once-proud hockey team lose more often than it won.
 
The announcement on Wednesday of the team’s move to the Barclays Center in Brooklyn,
title: With Islanders’ Move, Pondering Tailgating on Train

body: Brooklyn giveth and Brooklyn taketh away. The borough that carried a victim's posture for half a century is now collecting sports franchises. But Brooklyn cannot carry away the
title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES; Islanders Leaving, the Glory Long Gone

body: Championship boxing returned to Brooklyn on Saturday night for the first time in 81 years. The borough deserted by baseball's Dodgers in the 1950s and now embraced by the N.B.A.'s Nets, held four title bouts at the newly built Barclays Center. title: Brooklyn Welcomes Back Title Fights

title: MUSIC REVIEW; A Sentimental Journey

title: IT'S THE ECONOMY; What's a $4,000 Suit worth?

title: FALL RESTAURANT PREVIEW; Chefs Try New Terrain, Like the Upper East Side

body: Prehistory 1. MASTODON TUSK, ABOUT 11,000 B.C. The bedrock of Manhattan formed a billion years ago, much later guiding the development of downtown and Midtown. title: A History of New York in 50 Objects

title: F.Y.I.; Answers to Questions About New York

body: A woman was killed and three people were wounded in a shooting Thursday night in Brooklyn, the police said. One of the wounded was a 13-year-old boy, who was grazed in the back, the police said. The others were a 26-year-old man and a 29-year-old man. The shooting took place shortly after 9 p.m. on Clarkson Avenue near Flatbush Avenue, at the
title: Woman Dies in Brooklyn Shooting

body: The Fulton Street Mall in Downtown Brooklyn has been changing rapidly in recent years, as national retail chains flock to the mall, a shopping strip that once housed local sneaker stores and jewelry repair shops. body: THIS morning, I grabbed a bowl from the cabinet, went outside and picked my breakfast of fresh figs . No, I'm not vacationing near the Mediterranean coast. Nor am I in California or the South. title: A GOOD APPETITE; Italy to Brooklyn, Fig by Fig

body: IT took a while for Athanasios Biros to solve the mystery of his noisy upstairs neighbor. Mr. Biros, 35, who works for a bank, at first suspected a bartender with odd working hours lived above his studio in Greenwich Village. Then he heard a pounding noise at 7 in the morning. ''I just snapped,'' he said. He knocked on the door, and met his
title: Sleepwalk to Work

body: So Very FrenchSeveral food festivals created by groups from France are planned for late September. title: Calendar

A piece of driftwood like a long bone pins magazines to a battered coffee table.Clay pitchers and a
title: HUNGRY CITY; The Food Is Hot; The Mood Is Cool

body: 'TANGLE' It's chaotic yet controlled. Linear but scrambled. Scripted while improvised. Stationary though moving. It's an oxymoron, a paradox, a conundrum. title: Spare Times: For Children

body: At one point in ''Crossing Brooklyn Ferry,'' Walt Whitman's great meditation on the transit between Manhattan and Brooklyn, Whitman rhapsodizes about the ''islands large and small'' perched in the harbor. Among them presumably was Governors Island, at that time still a military installation. The Miser wonders what Whitman would make of the crowds
title: WEEKEND MISER; Poetry on Governors Island

body: For months, labor organizers in Brooklyn had been holding late-night strategy sessions and visiting workers' homes. Now, all they could do was wait. Ballots were being tallied in the basement of a Key Food supermarket. The outcome of the vote would determine whether the store's workers would join a union. Finally, a union representative emerged.
title: Labor Efforts Over Conditions at Greengrocers Split 2 Immigrant Groups

body: At first glance, the urban jungle of New York might seem an inhospitable place for golf. But look again. There go two guys, clubs draped over their shoulders, hustling across West 34th Street and into Pennsylvania Station. A teenager rides the subway on a summer weekday to a nine-hole course in the Bronx, trading in his backpack for a golf bag.
title: ON PAR; Concrete Jungle, but an Oasis Is Never Far Away

body: SEMANTICALLY speaking, the Hampton Jitney, with its fleet of luxury coaches, long ago outgrew its name. But if you are trying to hustle your way to some sand and sun this summer with just a few dollars in your pocket, there is a van waiting for you at North Seventh Street and Bedford Avenue in Brooklyn. For $6 each way, Alexis Van Lines shuttles
title: To the Queens Riviera, For a Few Dollars Less

body: A FEW weeks ago, Nike released the Air Yeezy 2, a more abundant and less daring shoe than the original but still a rare and coveted one, reportedly limited to 3,000 pairs. title: CRITICAL SHOPPER; Cool Shoes for All

body: In sleek black sedans and unmarked blue vans, stretch limousines and family-friendly S.U.V.'s, the city's unlicensed taxi drivers have long thrived on a simple fact: Officials often could not seize their cars because there was no place to put them. title: Benefactor Fills a Hole in the City's Effort to Enforce a Taxi Law

title: THE HOT LIST; From 20 Critics, A Ticket to Summer

body: A woman was fatally shot by a plainclothes New York City police detective on Thursday after running a series of red lights in a stolen vehicle in Brooklyn, colliding head-on with a minivan, then scrambling to evade the police, the authorities said. The woman, 23, whose name was not immediately released, was not armed, said Paul J. Browne, the
title: Officer Fatally Shoots Woman After Crash in Brooklyn

body: 'Starball' Every musical has its stars. But even the best of Broadway won't blaze as brightly as some key players in an unusual production on Saturday in Manhattan. These stars have the night sky as their stage, represented by the roof of the Hayden Planetarium at the American Museum of Natural History. There the audience will help write the drama,
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: For Children 'GO WITH THE FLOW' New York is a city of bridges, and majestic as those steel spans may be, they also bring noise, traffic and exhaust fumes. But on Saturday families can rediscover one that's quiet, free of automobiles and leads to an island filled with more greenery than concrete. This bridge is made for walking. Stretching from
title: Spare Times

body: THIRTEEN years ago, no one in Manhattan went to Brooklyn for dinner by choice. You had to dangle Peter Luger as bait, and a car service back to ''the city,'' or at least an escort to the subway. Then Emiliano Coppa and Anna Klinger, a Venetian and an American who had fallen in love in Italy and settled in Brooklyn, opened Al di Là in Park Slope.
title: HUNGRY CITY; In Crown Heights, Malfatti for the Trilbys

body: OPENING AGATA & VALENTINA There is indeed an Agata -- Agata Musco, who owns the longtime Italian market on the Upper East Side with her husband, Joe Musco, and Louis Balducci. The Muscos' daughter, Valentina Musco Puleo, is also a partner in the store. Now, after 19 years, they are branching out. Their new store downtown, in rustic Sicilian style,
title: Off the Menu

author: An artist and musician.
body: THIS summer the city's Department of Transportation inaugurates a new bike-share program. People who live and work in New York will be able to travel quickly and cheaply between many neighborhoods. This is major. It will make New Yorkers rethink their city and rewrite the mental maps we use to decide what is convenient, what is possible. Parks,
title: OPINION; This Is How We Ride

body: The conundrum that Samuel I. title: Arena Traffic Plan Cuts Parking Slots by Half

body: IF one motto could be said to have guided all those responsible for the waves of development sustained by Downtown Brooklyn over the years, it might have been ''Think no small thoughts.'' title: LIVING IN | DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN; To the Heights and the Slope, Add 'Downtown'

body: IN seventh-grade English class, sun leaked in through the windows. Horns bleated outside. The assignment was for the arrayed students to identify a turning point in their lives. Was it positive or negative? They hunched over and wrote fervidly. Floriande Augustin, a first-year teacher at the school, invited students to share their choices. Hands
title: A SYSTEM DIVIDED; 'Why Don't We Have Any White Kids?'

author: As told to Elizabeth Olson.
body: I GREW up in Brooklyn, on Flatbush Avenue near Prospect Park. One of my earliest memories is of learning to use a hand dolly to move boxes. My father, who was a truck driver, later taught me how to operate a forklift and, when I was old enough, to drive an 18-wheeler. I had two older sisters, and when one of them was mugged for the third time, my
title: THE BOSS; Forklifts to Photography

body: They may not be the luckiest people in the world, but Brooklyn people who want to see Barbra Streisand struck a jackpot of sorts Wednesday: the singer confirmed that she is returning to her home turf, to perform for the first time since she graduated from Erasmus Hall High School as a fiercely ambitious teenager and became, well, Barbra Streisand.
title: CITY ROOM; A Streisand Encore, 5 Decades Overdue

body: EVERY year, spring brings with it the promise of new planting, home improvement projects and renovations. body: Marty Markowitz was 12 years old when the Dodgers shattered his adolescent heart and left Ebbets Field for Los Angeles. He even took part in a demonstration to press the team's owner, Walter O'Malley, to change his mind, a baby step in the political career he capped by becoming Brooklyn's borough president. ''I cried like a baby,'' Mr. Markowitz
title: In Hapless Nets, Hope for Jilted Borough

body: 'THE BUTTERFLY' Totalitarian regimes need children: not their participation, but their loyalty. title: Spare Times: For Children

title: CITY ROOM; On the Sidewalk, Peddling a Game That Was Played on the Street

body: Moey's Princess Ball Melissa Levis's career as a children's performer began with a very bad hair day. Actually, several very bad hair months. Her son, Monty, a toddler, was flatly refusing shampoo. ''So,'' she said, ''I wrote a song called 'Pierre Wouldn't Wash His Hair.' '' That ballad describes a boy with hair so filthy that a bird drops a seed

body: The battle over Atlantic Yards has already raged longer than the Civil War, with eight years of protests, petitions and lawsuits seeking to halt a project that promised to reshape the heart of Brooklyn. title: Impact of Atlantic Yards, for Good or Ill, Is Already Felt

body: La-keeyatta Steward, 17, sat on a small black pillow one recent Tuesday afternoon, her legs tucked under her. Her meditation instructor told her to imagine her body pulled upward by a string, so she lowered her shoulders and straightened her back. Then two of her classmates burst in. ''There was a brawl,'' called Ian Alsopp, 18, shaking his head.
title: CITY ROOM; Zen for High Schoolers: 'Notice the Anxiety. Notice the Fear.'

body: The urban dictionary gives several definitions for ''weekender,'' including a youth who works a boring weekday job just to pay for raves and drugs on the weekend; a busy significant other who is never around during the workweek; and, the Miser's favorite, a person who enjoys life more than most. The Dekalb Market embraces that last description with
title: WEEKEND MISER; Dekalb Market Kicks Off Season With Live Music

title: Putting In Their 2 Cents

body: New York Road Runners will reconfigure the course of the Brooklyn Half Marathon so that nearly three times as many runners can join the race in May. title: Brooklyn Race Open to More Runners

body: Triangle Sports has occupied the same three-cornered site on Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn since 1916. But in January, the store's owners put the 1,570-square-foot parcel on the market. What motivated them was the behemoth across the street -- the Barclays Center, the 19,000-seat arena where the Nets will play, and which is expected to open in just
title: In Barclays Center's Shadow, Awaiting What's Next

body: Norfolk State had only just polished off its upset of second-seeded Missouri on Friday night when Chuck Granby's phone started ringing. And ringing. ''Man, people have been calling me who I haven't spoken to in years,'' Granby, the coach at Campus Magnet High School in Queens, said with a chuckle. It was to be expected. One of Granby's former
title: WEST REGION; Norfolk State's Roots Run Through New York City

body: There is one Caribbean island that does not demand a long flight: Manhattan. The number of West Indians in New York City renders it unofficially tropical even during cruel winters, which means Caribbean music pervades the city's night-life scene. Thursday nights are all about Vice, a fantastically high-energy Trinidadian after-work party at Studio
title: More Island Music: New York City

title: CITY ROOM; For Older Gay Men and Lesbians, a Place Like Home, Complete With $2 Dinners

body: 'The Festival of the Vegetables' Gingerbread men may run, and sugarplums dance, but vegetables in children's stories tend to act like, well, vegetables. body: For more than 24 hours, New York police detectives searched for a man they believed had shot and critically wounded the 25-year-old daughter of his girlfriend in the far reaches of the Rockaways, in Queens. On Tuesday, detectives caught up with the man, Michael McBride, 52, on the other side of the city as he walked along West 145th Street near his
title: Fleeing Suspect Fires On Officer, Then Is Fatally Shot, at an Uptown Subway Station

body: It's easy to fall in love with a neighborhood in New York. And given the high cost of housing, it's common to realize that you can't afford the home you want in the neighborhood you love. So, what to do? Your first instinct may be to look a few stops away on the same subway line, trading Williamsburg for Bushwick, for instance. Or you might choose
title: You're Priced Out. Now What?

body: Opening ALISON EIGHTEEN Alison Price Becker's return to the Manhattan restaurant scene after an absence of almost 10 years conjures memories of her previous restaurant, Alison on Dominick Street. title: Off the Menu
